Question: How bad is this PET Scan result? Testicular cancer patient. Explanation of scan would be helpful. 27M - 6â€™7â€ù, 225lbs. White. Generally healthy before cancer. Seminoma did not present physically, only presentation was severe back pain. I have had other back issues so I lived in pain for close to a year. Went to oncologist per ER referral and Ultrasound confirmed seminoma. I got a pet scan today after completing chemo last week. I was very optimistic and my doctor has given me no reason to suspect there would be any problems. He said 95% sure chemo would take care of it. I am going to paste the results that were posted on my patient portal below. I am a big boy and a logical thinker please Donâ€™t sugar coat theses results, translate and explain if possible. I was expecting good news but I can tell this is not. I can have peace if I understand it. My follow up with my oncologist is not until next week and Iâ€™m very anxious and want to understand. Begin Results:â€”â€”â€”â€”-:Impression:1.Hypermetabolic left hilar lymph node unchanged in size from prior exam. Calcification present. Metastatic disease cannot be excluded as this node was not hypermetabolic on prior exam. 2. Much improvement in retroperitoneal adenopathy in both size of lymph nodes, extent of lymph nodes, and decrease in hypermetabolic activity compared to prior exam. 3. No other areas of metastatic disease suspected.Findings:1. There is a calcified left hilar lymph node unchanged in size from prior exam probably about 1 cm in short axis measurements with a maximum SUV today of 5.3 and previously not hypermetabolic maximum activity 2.0.2.  The previously noted large intra-aortocaval lymph node has markedly decreased in size and on today's exam is subcentimeter in short axis measurements with a maximum SUV of 6.8 whereas previously maximum SUV was 16.6.3.  More inferiorly in the intra-aortocaval region of the retroperitoneum where multiple previous adjacent hypermetabolic lymph nodes were seen with a maximum SUV of 20.8, on today's exam 1 lymph node measuring roughly 8 mm in short axis measurement is present maximum SUV 6.8.
Physician Response: A PET scan obtained right after finishing chemotherapy increases the likelihood of false positive results. It takes time for your body to clean up after chemotherapy or surgery or radiation. The residual activity that a PET scan captures in the active areas can take a few months to calm down. The presence of hypermetabolic areas is not unexpected when it was only a week since your last treatment. The fact that the areas of activity noted on prior scans are now smaller is good news. It strongly suggests that your cancer is responding to treatment. The new spot in your chest (the hilar node) may or may not be significant. There are other things that can cause a node to light up on PET scan. The presence of calcifications in a node is usually an indication of benign causes, rather than malignant causes of hypermetabolic activity. The only way to know for sure is a biopsy, which they probably won't recommend right now. Note: I am not an oncologist. Talk to your doctor about the results and the plan for follow-up. Good luck!

Physician Response: D-dimer is a byproduct of clot formation, so anytime a clot forms some d-dimer will form as well. The bigger the clot the more the d-dimer. Naturally the body is constantly forming clots from microtrauma to blood vessels due to normal wear and tear. But also after getting an injury, like blood drawn for lab work. Ultimately that means that you will always have some d-dimer amount in your blood. Which is what makes it a horrible test in most applications, very sensitive to almost anything and very not specific to almost anything.Troponin is a protein that is part of muscle, in your case they were looking for cardiac troponin (from the heart). It is only supposed to be in the heart muscle cells. If any of it is in the blood that means there was heart muscle breakdown and the troponin "leaked" into the blood from within the muscle cells of the heart. Physician Response: Atelectasis isnâ€™t an uncommon finding. It just means your lung in that area is not being inflated. It is indeed collapsed. This can be for any number of reason but for most it is due to lack of exercise or activity. Itâ€™s also common in those with recurrent infections or get bronchitis because gunk builds up and blocks airways from getting proper aeration. Typically when you work your body, you tend to breath in harder which opens up all portions of your lungs. Your lungs are made up of tons of tiny little balloons (alveoli). The balloons at the bottom of your lung sometimes need extra force to really open them up. In your case, if you have scarring in that area, it may be even harder to inflate. Atelectasis is when the balloons collapse and havenâ€™t been opened up in some time. It looks like your lung tissue has shrunken but typically isnâ€™t a problem unless a large portion of your lung is affected. If youâ€™ve never tried one, a spirometer might be beneficial to help open up this portion of your lung. Guaifenesin to clear out mucus may also help. It can also be painful to open that portion of the lung up if atelectasis has been long standing.
